Colin, thanks for highlighting the normalization issue.  Indeed I think thi=
s issue has come up from time to time.  I agree with your sentiment about t=
he second equation being better and it is the one we used and that is imple=
mented in my version of NEAT.  However, we included the normalization terms=
 in our publications (noting that they don't need to be used) because we we=
re not certain that the time whether normalization might turn out important=
 at large network sizes.  So we wanted to at least raise the possibility.  =
Unfortunately it resulted in some confusion over what was the "standard" wa=
y to do it.  In any case, I do generally endorse the second way but I think=
 both can be calibrated to work, as shown in ANJI, which does do the normal=
ization.

I also believe there are likely more principled speciation approa=
ches than the kind of simplistic way it is done in my oriignal implementati=
on, as you have been exploring.  I'm looking forward to seeing SharpNEAT 2.=
0!

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "alienseedpod" <colin.green1@...> w=
rote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> Earlier in the year I kicked off a discussion about =
genome compatibility metrics (AKA distance or similarity metrics). SharpNea=
t 2 (SN2) is nearing release and allows metrics to be plugged and thus comp=
ared, there's a bit more to it than that and I'm currently writing some doc=
umentation to explain how this will work along with some issues to keep in =
mind, pros and cons, etc.
> 
> Anyway in writing up this stuff I ended up d=
ocumenting how the original metric works, as described in the original NEAT=
 paper in 2002. Now I've got a suspicion that this came up long ago but in =
that paper the distance is given as:
> 
>    d =3D c1*E/N + c2*D/N + c3*W
>=
 
> (E,D are the # of excess and disjoint genes. W is the total weight diff=
).
> 
> N is the number of genes in the longest genome. So the contribution=
 of excess/disjoint genes to d is normalized. In Ken's original code this e=
quation is commented out and replaced with the equivalent of:
> 
>    d =3D=
 c1*E + c2*D + c3*W
> 
> This makes more sense to me, it puts far more emph=
asis on the difference in topology than the first version and is sort of re=
lated to edit distance and manhattan distance. 
> 
> For the record SN1 als=
o uses the latter equation and the other implementation I checked just now =
was ANJI2 which uses the former. Not sure what the implications of this are=
 but I suspect it would have a significant effect on speciation with second=
ary effects from there. Others may wish to review the metric in their imple=
mentations.
> 
> Colin.
>
